clusters.title: Facing meltdown? Over 75% of people suffer from burnout - here’s what you need to know
clusters.neutral_headline: Facing meltdown Over 75% of people suffer from burnout - here’s what you need to know

items.title: Facing meltdown? Over 75% of people suffer from burnout - here’s what you need to know
items.standfirst: Does it only affect weak people? Is work always the cause? Burnout myths, busted by the expertsOnce, after surviving yet another round of redundancies in a former job, I did something very odd. I turned off the lights in my room and lay face-down on the bed, unable to move. Rather than feeling relief at having escaped the axe, I was exhausted and numb. I’m not the only one. Fatigue, apathy and hopelessness are all textbook signs of burnout, a bleak phenomenon that has come to define many of our working lives. In 2025, a report from Moodle found that 66% of US workers had experienced some kind of burnout, while a Mental Health UK survey found that one in three adults came under high levels of pressure or stress in the previous year. Despite the prevalence of burnout, plenty of misconceptions around it persist. “Everybody thinks it’s some sort of disease or medical condition,” says Christina Maslach, the psychology professor who was the first to study the syndrome in the 1970s. “But it’s actually a response to chronic job stressors – a stress response.” Here we separate the facts from the myths. Continue reading...
items.content: Does it only affect weak people? Is work always the cause? Burnout myths, busted by the expertsOnce, after surviving yet another round of redundancies in a former job, I did something very odd. I turned off the lights in my room and lay face-down on the bed, unable to move. Rather than feeling relief at having escaped the axe, I was exhausted and numb. I’m not the only one. Fatigue, apathy and hopelessness are all textbook signs of burnout, a bleak phenomenon that has come to define many of our working lives. In 2025, a report from Moodle found that 66% of US workers had experienced some kind of burnout, while a Mental Health UK survey found that one in three adults came under high levels of pressure or stress in the previous year. Despite the prevalence of burnout, plenty of misconceptions around it persist. “Everybody thinks it’s some sort of disease or medical condition,” says Christina Maslach, the psychology professor who was the first to study the syndrome in the 1970s. “But it’s actually a response to chronic job stressors – a stress response.” Here we separate the facts from the myths. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Over 75% of people experience burnout
Burnout is a response to chronic job stressors
Fatigue and apathy are common symptoms
Burnout affects people in various professions
Experts work to dispel misconceptions about burnout

clusters.title: ‘You think: Do I really need anyone?’ – the hidden burden of being a hyper-independent person
clusters.neutral_headline: The hidden burden of being a hyper-independent person

items.title: ‘You think: Do I really need anyone?’ – the hidden burden of being a hyper-independent person
items.standfirst: Self-reliance is often encouraged over asking others for help in the modern world. But doing everything yourself can be a sign that you are scared of intimacyWhen a relative was seriously ill and in intensive care for more than a month, Cianne Jones stepped in. “I took it upon myself to be that person in the hospital every single day – chasing doctors, taking notes, making sure I understood why they were doing things.” It was so stressful, she says, that at one point her hair started falling out, but she ploughed on.It was Jones’s therapist who gently questioned whether she was going to ask for help. Jones laughs. “The hair falling out didn’t suggest to me that I needed help, it was somebody else looking in and saying that.” She has a large, close family who would have helped immediately – and did, once Jones asked – it’s just that it didn’t occur to her to ask. “I had taken that role on: ‘I’m just going to get everything done.’ I just took off, and that was it.” Continue reading...
items.content: Self-reliance is often encouraged over asking others for help in the modern world. But doing everything yourself can be a sign that you are scared of intimacyWhen a relative was seriously ill and in intensive care for more than a month, Cianne Jones stepped in. “I took it upon myself to be that person in the hospital every single day – chasing doctors, taking notes, making sure I understood why they were doing things.” It was so stressful, she says, that at one point her hair started falling out, but she ploughed on.It was Jones’s therapist who gently questioned whether she was going to ask for help. Jones laughs. “The hair falling out didn’t suggest to me that I needed help, it was somebody else looking in and saying that.” She has a large, close family who would have helped immediately – and did, once Jones asked – it’s just that it didn’t occur to her to ask. “I had taken that role on: ‘I’m just going to get everything done.’ I just took off, and that was it.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: Hyper-independent people often hide their struggles
Self-reliance can be a sign of fear of intimacy
Hyper-independent individuals may neglect self-care
Therapists help hyper-independent people open up
Hyper-independence can lead to physical and mental exhaustion

clusters.title: What is colorectal cancer and is it preventable?
clusters.neutral_headline: What is colorectal cancer and is it preventable?

items.title: What is colorectal cancer and is it preventable?
items.standfirst: Cases among younger people are rising – such as with actor James Van Der Beek, who died on 11 February at age 48Actor James Van Der Beek died on 11 February, aged 48; he had been diagnosed in 2023 with colorectal cancer.According to the World Health Organization, colorectal cancer is the third most common cancer and the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide. While rates are declining overall, cases among younger people are rising. Continue reading...
items.content: Cases among younger people are rising – such as with actor James Van Der Beek, who died on 11 February at age 48Actor James Van Der Beek died on 11 February, aged 48; he had been diagnosed in 2023 with colorectal cancer.According to the World Health Organization, colorectal cancer is the third most common cancer and the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths worldwide. While rates are declining overall, cases among younger people are rising. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Colorectal cancer is a common and deadly disease
Cases among younger people are increasing
Colorectal cancer is the third most common cancer
The disease is often preventable with screening
Early detection improves treatment outcomes

items.title: ‘Nothing says love like chemicals’: Valentine’s roses often covered in pesticides, testing finds
items.standfirst: Bouquets imported to Europe found to be heavily contaminated, often with chemicals banned in EU and UKStay away from roses this Valentine’s Day, environmental campaigners have warned after testing revealed them to be heavily contaminated with pesticides.Laboratory testing on bouquets in the Netherlands, Europe’s flower import hub, found roses had the highest residues of neurological and reproductive toxins compared with other flowers. clusters.title: Vaping in cars carrying children to be banned in England
clusters.neutral_headline: Vaping in cars with children to be banned in England

items.title: Vaping in cars carrying children to be banned in England
items.standfirst: Rising evidence that secondhand vapour from e-cigarettes poses health risks, government saysVaping in cars carrying anyone under 18 will be banned in England under government plans to reduce the harm caused by smoking and e-cigarettes.The move is included in the tobacco and vapes bill, which will also outlaw smoking, vaping and using heated tobacco in playgrounds and outside schools and hospitals. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

New rules to protect children from secondhand vapour
Government cites rising evidence of health risks

clusters.title: ‘A different set of rules’: thermal drone footage shows Musk’s AI power plant flouting clean air regulations
clusters.neutral_headline: Thermal drone footage shows Musk’s AI power plant flouting clean air regulations

items.title: ‘A different set of rules’: thermal drone footage shows Musk’s AI power plant flouting clean air regulations
items.standfirst: Images confirm xAI is continuing to defy EPA regulations in Mississippi to power its flagship datacentersElon Musk’s artificial intelligence company is continuing to fuel its datacenters with unpermitted gas turbines, an investigation by the Floodlight newsroom shows. Thermal footage captured by Floodlight via drone shows xAI is still burning gas at a facility in Southaven, Mississippi, despite a recent Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) ruling reiterating that doing so requires a state permit in advance.State regulators in Mississippi maintain that since the turbines are parked on tractor trailers, they don’t require permits. However, the EPA has long maintained that such pollution sources require permits under the Clean Air Act. Continue reading...
items.content: Images confirm xAI is continuing to defy EPA regulations in Mississippi to power its flagship datacentersElon Musk’s artificial intelligence company is continuing to fuel its datacenters with unpermitted gas turbines, an investigation by the Floodlight newsroom shows. Thermal footage captured by Floodlight via drone shows xAI is still burning gas at a facility in Southaven, Mississippi, despite a recent Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) ruling reiterating that doing so requires a state permit in advance.State regulators in Mississippi maintain that since the turbines are parked on tractor trailers, they don’t require permits. However, the EPA has long maintained that such pollution sources require permits under the Clean Air Act. Continue reading...

ai_summary: xAI uses unpermitted gas turbines to power datacenters
EPA ruling requires state permit for gas turbines
Mississippi regulators claim turbines do not require permits
Thermal footage shows xAI burning gas without permit
EPA maintains pollution sources require permits under Clean Air Act

clusters.title: When it comes to mental health labels, we need to tread lightly | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Mental health labels need careful consideration

items.title: When it comes to mental health labels, we need to tread lightly | Letters
items.standfirst: Readers respond to a long read article by Gavin Francis in which he voices concern that current approaches to labelling and diagnosis may be doing more harm than goodThank you, Gavin Francis, for your long read (‘What I see in clinic is never a set of labels’: are we in danger of overdiagnosing mental illness?, 10 February). It powerfully captures some of the traps modern psychiatry finds itself in and beautifully describes the all-important – and indeed, threatened – relationship at the heart of any good doctor’s practice. I have been a psychiatrist and psychotherapist for over 40 years and would like to make two points about the “epidemic” of mental illness now upon us.First, there is a mass of evidence that shows mental ill-being, suffering and disturbance, at all degrees of severity, are affected by the level of inequality in society and by social hardship such as poverty, violence and discrimination. Between them, this explains some of the increase we are seeing. Continue reading...
items.content: Readers respond to a long read article by Gavin Francis in which he voices concern that current approaches to labelling and diagnosis may be doing more harm than goodThank you, Gavin Francis, for your long read (‘What I see in clinic is never a set of labels’: are we in danger of overdiagnosing mental illness?, 10 February). It powerfully captures some of the traps modern psychiatry finds itself in and beautifully describes the all-important – and indeed, threatened – relationship at the heart of any good doctor’s practice. I have been a psychiatrist and psychotherapist for over 40 years and would like to make two points about the “epidemic” of mental illness now upon us.First, there is a mass of evidence that shows mental ill-being, suffering and disturbance, at all degrees of severity, are affected by the level of inequality in society and by social hardship such as poverty, violence and discrimination. Between them, this explains some of the increase we are seeing. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Overdiagnosing mental illness may be doing more harm
Modern psychiatry finds itself in traps and challenges
Mental ill-being affected by social inequality and hardship
Poverty and discrimination contribute to mental illness
Good doctor-patient relationships are essential for diagnosis

clusters.title: Arundhati Roy is right, not Wim Wenders – here are eight films that have changed politics
clusters.neutral_headline: Arundhati Roy is right not Wim Wenders on films changing politics

items.title: Arundhati Roy is right, not Wim Wenders – here are eight films that have changed politics
items.standfirst: From ‘honour’ killings to nuclear war, some screen works have led directly legislative action – despite what jury head Wenders suggested at the Berlin film festivalShould film festivals be more than just screenings and red carpets? Should they prompt us to think about the role cinema plays in the world? Novelist Arundhati Roy certainly thinks so. She pulled out of appearing at the Berlin festival in protest at jury president Wim Wenders’ claim that films should “stay out of politics”; she said Wenders’ stance was “unconscionable”, and that to “hear [him] say that art should not be political is jaw-dropping.”Wenders had suggested that cinema is a way to build empathy, but not directly change politicians’ minds. However this is simply not true. Some films – both documentary and narrative – have not only changed public opinion about social issues but led directly to legislation. Despite evidence to the contrary, politicians are people too. They can be moved. And sometimes they are even moved to action. Continue reading...
items.content: From ‘honour’ killings to nuclear war, some screen works have led directly legislative action – despite what jury head Wenders suggested at the Berlin film festivalShould film festivals be more than just screenings and red carpets? Should they prompt us to think about the role cinema plays in the world? Novelist Arundhati Roy certainly thinks so. She pulled out of appearing at the Berlin festival in protest at jury president Wim Wenders’ claim that films should “stay out of politics”; she said Wenders’ stance was “unconscionable”, and that to “hear [him] say that art should not be political is jaw-dropping.”Wenders had suggested that cinema is a way to build empathy, but not directly change politicians’ minds. However this is simply not true. Some films – both documentary and narrative – have not only changed public opinion about social issues but led directly to legislation. Despite evidence to the contrary, politicians are people too. They can be moved. And sometimes they are even moved to action. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Films can lead to legislative action and social change
Arundhati Roy criticizes Wim Wenders' stance on politics
Cinema can build empathy and change public opinion
Some films have directly influenced politicians and laws
Films can address social issues and prompt action

clusters.title: FDA refuses to consider Moderna flu shot in move experts claim is part of ‘anti-vaccine agenda’
clusters.neutral_headline: FDA refuses to consider Moderna flu shot in move experts claim is part of ‘anti-vaccine agenda’

items.title: FDA refuses to consider Moderna flu shot in move experts claim is part of ‘anti-vaccine agenda’
items.standfirst: Experts say ‘they’re just coming up with reasons’ as agency says application lacked ‘adequate and well controlled’ trialA senior US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) official says Moderna’s clinical trial on a new, potentially more effective flu vaccine was a “brazen failure” and that the FDA is now calling it into question.The FDA unexpectedly refused to consider Moderna’s application for a flu shot based on messenger RNA (mRNA) technology in a decision that experts say is already having a chilling effect on vaccine development. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts say ‘they’re just coming up with reasons’ as agency says application lacked ‘adequate and well controlled’ trialA senior US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) official says Moderna’s clinical trial on a new, potentially more effective flu vaccine was a “brazen failure” and that the FDA is now calling it into question.The FDA unexpectedly refused to consider Moderna’s application for a flu shot based on messenger RNA (mRNA) technology in a decision that experts say is already having a chilling effect on vaccine development. Continue reading...

ai_summary: FDA refuses Moderna flu shot application due to trial issues
Experts claim FDA decision is part of anti-vaccine agenda
Moderna flu shot uses messenger RNA technology
FDA requires adequate and well controlled trials
Experts say decision will have chilling effect on vaccine development
